First, I start with the earnings. If the numbers are significantly better than what the Street is expecting—say, revenue is up 30% instead of the projected 10%—I know the stock is going to pop. I’ll quietly accumulate shares in the days leading up to the release, making sure not to leave a digital footprint. I use a mix of shell accounts and offshore brokers to mask the flow of capital. The idea is to look like a normal investor, not a whale sniffing for a setup.

But I don’t stop there. I look for the *subtext*. Maybe the company is guiding conservatively, but the actual numbers are way stronger. That tells me the stock is undervalued and the market will react strongly once the truth comes out. I might also look at segment performance. If a particular division is outperforming expectations—say, Alibaba Cloud is crushing it—I’ll position myself in that segment’s related stocks or even look at suppliers or partners that benefit from the growth.

I also pay close attention to the management commentary. Subtle shifts in tone can signal a lot. If the CEO is unusually bullish or the CFO is hinting at a major strategic pivot, that’s a red flag for me. I want to know *before* the public does. I’ll also check for any upcoming announcements—M&A, product launches, or regulatory changes. If there's a pending acquisition or a new product that’s going to disrupt the sector, I’ll get in early.

Once I’ve identified the targets, I execute with precision. I don’t just buy and hold. I scale in over time, using limit orders and wash trades to blend in. I also hedge where appropriate. If the company is in a sector I’m long on, I might short a competitor or use options to lock in profits.

But the real art is knowing when to exit. I don’t wait for the peak. I sell in waves—first a small portion once the initial move hits, then more as the momentum builds. I leave just enough behind to look like a regular investor, not a manipulator. That way, if anyone ever suspects something, they’ll chalk it up to luck, not strategy.
